title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: Her own proper den was in a flat on the ground floor of a house in Windmill Street, where her sole companion was a single female servant. When the servant went out, which she generally took the liberty of doing for the whole of Sunday, Suphy s

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: It is in this street that Mr. Wm. Gibson has his fineshop for jewellery, &c. Opposite the end of the Haymarket is GreatWindmill Street, named from a windmill which two hundred years agostood near; and where, until the autumn of 1878, were the notoriousArgyle Rooms, in which most of the old and young roues and fast womenused to assemble for dancing. It is now done away with.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: Finding that he could not see, he uttered a few words, which have been variously given, but all the accounts of which mean " It is getting dark, boys ; we must put off the rest till to-morrow." It was the darkness of death. He was followed to the grave (in the Chapel of Ease near Windmill Street) by many eminent and grateful pupils. James Pillans, his successor, has given a good short sketch of him in the Encyclopaedia Britaimica.
